[8281354]

First time as a Mush, I waited, got in good with the crew, and bode my time. Finally, they launch an expedition... without securing the hacker kit! I went looking to see if I could encounter it easily, and did, loaded a fuel, and ran up to the bridge, grabbing a lens on the way to go with the blaster I had been holding. On the bridge, I spammed the hacker kit. No luck, no luck, no luck.... success! Except.... I forgot you needed AP to move the ship, and I had no more. So I used my shooter points to headshot Frieda, and shot Paola but couldn't kill her. I was going to leave an RP message to the crew since I was well and truly outed and could do nothing more, but I was killed before I could.

(If any of that crew stumbles in here, it was "Hkkkgh, tHIs vesseL has fAileD us. MAnY vessEls have faiLEd uS. But tHEre are Many, mANy moRe. Do nOT be fOoliSh, humanssss. SUbmiT....." )

On august 7, 2014
[8281354]
ChimeSo those Nova-things are also Glory bound? Didn't know.

Yup! It's just compared to the rest of the crew rather than a certain threshold, though. That's why it matters more than just flat Glory - useful crew members usually get more glory than less useful ones.


Misterme7Oxygen is zero. Roland gets lost on expo, Frieda kills herself. Icarus is lost, so I find him in a patrol ship. Still no oxygen, I land again. It puts Roland instead of me on the expo.

Ouch. X) So launching in a fighter is like launching from an overfilled Icarus bay.... if it makes you feel better, you could still die from oxygen loss on the planet. The real fail would be if he got lost again.
On august 7, 2014
Chime
IsidarthYup! It's just compared to the rest of the crew rather than a certain threshold, though. That's why it matters more than just flat Glory - useful crew members usually get more glory than less useful ones.

I might be mistaken but, if the one with the most glory always gets gold, the second excellent and the third the honor nova... Then there is just no difference between the normal glory list and the Nova list. It's plain useless. o,O' And doesn't say anything about the usefulness of a crew member.

On august 7, 2014
[8281354]

Mostly useless, but not quite. An active, helpful player is more likely to get glory by helping around the ship, participating in expos, and killing mush, and if a person has many of these awards listed on their profile, it's a mark of somebody who actually tries. The best method is probably to see how many likes they've collected.
On august 8, 2014
SummerMcLovin

Certain characters (e.g. Paola, Eleesha) don't really have a chance of top spots on long ships, but most ships with a few inactives and some later deaths will at least separate the more useful ones who survived from "the last nine places" Nova award.
On august 8, 2014
Misterme7

On august 8, 2014
npfan
ChimeI might be mistaken but, if the one with the most glory always gets gold, the second excellent and the third the honor nova... Then there is just no difference between the normal glory list and the Nova list. It's plain useless. o,O' And doesn't say anything about the usefulness of a crew member.

The two lists are very different. The glory list ranks by who has the most amount of glory in any one ship. The nova list ranks by who gets the top glory the most amount of times. Being at the top of both lists is almost impossible because the best way to earn the top spot in either list is completely opposite of each other.


IsidarthMostly useless, but not quite. An active, helpful player is more likely to get glory by helping around the ship, participating in expos, and killing mush, and if a person has many of these awards listed on their profile, it's a mark of somebody who actually tries. The best method is probably to see how many likes they've collected.

I really don't like using likes as a indicator of how good a player is because that system is inherently biased against effective Mush. For those of you that actually like a Mush that does their job, you're the exception, not the rule.
On august 8, 2014
Chime

If the first always get gold. And someone tends to be the first or second that way, aiming for as much glory as possible. Then it should be natural that he collects lot's of Gold Novas or Excellent Novas making him top the Nova Ranking aswell, no?
I don't really care though..

As for the likes and humans rarely liking mush. True. But seeing the numerous "Why aren't I picked mush more often" Thread/Complains I'd say that just makes a minimum of the games in which you will get less likes for being it.

(& I do "like" Mush that did their mush-part or acting-human-part good. Exceptions are those that go all "bwahahahayouidiottrololol" after their victory.)

On august 10, 2014
CraZy-gAEmeR

Recently, I was on a ship. The ship was going fine, Andie told people not to go into the Medlab because he was sleeping there, and Raluca tells people to keep out of Rear Alpha Turret.

Derek is killed by Raluca for going in the turret where she told people not to go. He was human.

Then Eleesha goes into the medlab saying she was checking to see if Andie has spored or anything. She is killed for this. She was human.

Terrence is dirty in alpha bay without saying why, so he is killed by Kuan-Ti. He was human.

Kuan-Ti, for no reason, kills Paola who was human. Because of this, me and Andie work together to kill Kuan-Ti. He was human.

At some point Ian dies of starvation. Obviously human.

I think Jin-Su dies at this point for being silent and not knowing what they are doing. They are human.

Chun dies of depression.

So we have 8 people dead and still 2 mush alive.

And then this happens:
At this point we are running low on oxygen so Roland suggests to me that we both scan for a planet. He tells me that he trusts me because I'm comforting and healing a lot. He asks me how much AP I have left to use for scanning planets.
...
He kills me 2 cycles later because the amount I said I had seemed a little low. I was human.

Dzanek

I had similar ship there
I was Eleesha, and I was helpless there because I couldn't investigate anything.

What's happened?
Frieda put a fire in both Dorms, took all entinguishers with the blueprint and hijacked one of ships. Terrence used the Hacker Kit and moved the ship. No firefighters, the ship was in fire. Our crew decide to kill the Mush quickly, repair the PILGRED and go back to Sol. Murder ship had begun.
Gioele was killed by Chun because he wasted AP for Kuboid. He was human.
Chun also killed Stephen because he was inactive. He was human.
Derek killed Jin Su because he wasn't talking and stayed dirty in the Lab since start the game, checking Research Lab. He was human.
Kuan Ti took 2 blasters, it was reason why Derek killed him. He was human.
Terrence killed Paola because altrough she managed to trade a hydropot for oxygen, she was the next suspicious person on list. She was human.
He also killed Derek because he didn't manage to kill the Mush. He was human.
I suspected Roland because he did PILGRED and was going around the ship without telling the reason. There were also problem with hunters all the time, and Roland had the same reason why he killed Hua. She was human.
I accused Roland and Raluca killed him. He was human.

Everybody knew I was human because of the disease. Janice helped Terrence leaving Frieda by loading fuel, and Raluca everybody agreed to finish PILGRED, and Raluca did. Andie and Ian were very fast with research (just 1 research done, but it was in 1 day, then we started to murder and repair the PILGRED). Anyway, Andie and Ian left for them, but Ian did research slower than Andie. They were going to kill Ian. It'd be the 9th murdered, but the fire destroyed the Daedalus first.

Jin Su here...

Let me tell you Deadmanwater about a few more fails on this.
- It was a fail that you became the leader of a secret team of "experts" for finding mush because you didn't find them and they killed you.

- It was a fail not visiting bravo dorm when I requested it from you because our morale was too low and you almost helped mush succeed with their demoralization plan. Let me explain this to you. You totally forgot your job of giving morale to the crew because you were too busy with finding the mush that killed you. Many crew members were at morale 5 - 6 including me. After they killed you, they demoralized Raluca 4 times. With your death and their (mush) death, everyone lost 3 morale and it was also near day change. Raluca would commit suicide which would be -1 morale plus -1 morale from day change for a total of -2 morale. At cycle change and without a shrink around, more would commit suicide dropping everyones morale even more etc. Fortunately, I bought gold and gave Raluca a few motivational speeches and she found herself alive when she logged in the next day. Also the team acted fast and moved the cat to those that needed morale but had no points to move.
- It was a fail that you picked the wrong people for your secret team. After your death all crew joined that channel and I took a look at your dialogs. Chun was not forwarding my reports to your secret channel and I did reported suspicious moves of one of the mushes.

By the way my friend, teens dont buy gold when the ship is in need. They stay bronze like Paola, because their daddy will not give them money for an upgrade. Keep that in mind and next time that there is a conflict, be an adult, man up and choose a side to end it. Your stance of staying out of something that irritates you, doesnt show maturity

I love you ALL!

On august 23, 2014
[6826491]
KobbOn the one I mentioned, we lost the Pasiphae to a human Roland who went on a spacewalk. He asked for help in chat, so either he literally had no clue what he was doing, or it was just an extra giggle for him to get out of his griefing.

I checked the logs for that ship - he was auto-ejected from the Pasiphae, as it exploded. At the very least, he didn't choose to eject. The game will force auto-ejection if the player has a spacesuit and the patrol ship/Pasiphae is destroyed.

(But as I recall, he collected scrap once, maybe twice, and then it exploded. I concluded that he had no idea that collecting scrap with hunters outside is that dangerous. He may have thought that the Pasiphae has weapons, too - a common newbie mistake.)

On august 23, 2014
[8281354]
SinfishMy ship insists that reading a book is mushlike behavior and nobody should read them until the mush are dead. Our starting magebook? Nurse. *facepalm*

For most magebooks I would agree with the crew. Some of them aren't harmful to have in mush hands (like radio expert), but there are a few that are super nice when you get to the late game - and a mush reading the book means the skill will be lost, either because the mush is dead or because of the skill reset with the serum injection. Those free ap from the nurse book are invaluable when people require frequent healing.

That said, "mushlike behavior" to read a useful book is stretching it. X)
On august 23, 2014
Tpyo
Isidarth

For most magebooks I would agree with the crew. Some of them aren't harmful to have in mush hands (like radio expert), but there are a few that are super nice when you get to the late game - and a mush reading the book means the skill will be lost, either because the mush is dead or because of the skill reset with the serum injection. Those free ap from the nurse book are invaluable when people require frequent healing.

That said, "mushlike behavior" to read a useful book is stretching it. X)

Tech, Pilot, and shooter come to mind, there's no rush to get those to people till the mush die. Medic and Biologist SHOULD be read before the mush are dead.
On august 23, 2014
Kyubey

Nurse book is not "invaluable". Nurse book is 2ap a day. Maybe 3ap, but that 3 can be replaced by 2 of other player. It's "useful", nothing more.
On august 23, 2014
[8281354]

Actually it's four AP per day- healing costs two. Not to mention they can be used for DIY surgery, saving you four... Maybe "invaluable" is a bit strong, but I've had it save lives on long ships. As for Medic/Biologist, I always advocate giving them to Chun, so mush or not is a moot point. X)
On august 23, 2014
SummerMcLovin

Except that you only get one Nurse point a day. It can be very helpful for a Silver Chun to have it to save herself in an emergency, but as a Mage Book not so much.

Wasting resources can be a Mush tactic, but many would (threaten to) kill you whether they suspected you or not. If you're willing to steal a Mage book, you might hoard the Scooter more, eat/drink unnecessarily etc. Same with any important tasks done without consulting the crew, choosing the 'wrong' Projects before voting, killing suspects that aren't definite etc.

I checked the logs for that ship - he was auto-ejected from the Pasiphae, as it exploded. At the very least, he didn't choose to eject. The game will force auto-ejection if the player has a spacesuit and the patrol ship/Pasiphae is destroyed.

On august 24, 2014
[6826491]
KobbSo if it had been a malicious ejection, would the Pasiphae have still been visible from turrets, just without a pilot (and possibly retrievable with Magnetic Net)? Or would it still have been permanently lost?

Yes, it would be visible from a turret, and with no pilot showing (the same as if a drone were piloting it.) And in that case, you could retrieve it via Magnetic Net.
On august 24, 2014
Kyubey

Yes, it would be visible from a turret, and with no pilot showing (the same as if a drone were piloting it.) And in that case, you could retrieve it via Magnetic Net.
Are you sure it still work like that? On one of patches of S4 I have seen, that patrol ships (I guess it means Pasiphae too) self-destruct if pilots ejects.
On august 24, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

There are a few weird bugs with ejection. If a pilot self-ejects from a patrol ship and you have Magnetic Net, the patrol ship will follow the Daedalus but won't land automatically (just like when they're piloted by drones). Which means that it's not destroyed, but it is lost anyway, because it will never come back aboard the ship.

There's also a bug that causes pilots to be ejected from broken or sabotaged patrol ships, and if the pilots don't have a spacesuit, they die from asphyxiation. And Neron makes a strange announcement that often has the crew believe that it was self-ejection, because the message doesn't start with the Neron icon but with that of the dead pilot.

SummerMcLovin
PatrykSzczescieIf I wasn't pilot, astrophysicist, comms manager or technician, I'd read this mage book and if they wanted to kill me if not, it'd be their trouble. If I died, I'd join the next ship, simply.

This is why people don't trust you and plan your murders so often

On august 24, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieIf I wasn't pilot, astrophysicist, comms manager or technician, I'd read this mage book and if they wanted to kill me if not, it'd be their trouble. If I died, I'd join the next ship, simply.

This attitude is why some people feel that reading a mage book without the consent of the crew is playing against the team. (On its own, it isn't - but it's often combined with other actions that make someone seem suspicious.)

Yes, it's up to them whether to kill you, but if you read the book with their consent (say, after being confirmed as human) then you don't put them in a position where they have to make that choice. And what happens when they do kill you because of that attitude? They lose an active player, suffer a morale hit, and the Mush get an easier voyage. Do you not see why this attitude can be harmful?
On august 24, 2014

They don't plan murders so often. Just you decide to kill me and one ship more, that's all, it isn't often.

On august 24, 2014
SummerMcLovin
PatrykSzczescieThat tactics: you know who you are, you know Chun is human, you don't know anything about other players.

So you wouldn't trust anyone else with it since they could all be Mush, I'm guessing? That goes both ways: just because you know you are human (and try to avoid proving that at all costs) doesn't mean that Chun or the rest of the crew (other than the Mush) do.

In a game of maybes they'd much rather have everything go with a definite yes if they can help it. If you try to do too much, like "oh I know I'm human so it isn't a problem if I get Dirty and then go to check on Raluca", it doesn't work out well. Maybe you got lucky on your past ships, maybe I was too harsh, but you can still try to keep yourself out of the firing line a bit more.
On august 24, 2014
[6826491]
KyubeyIllogical. Player who reads thinks he better understands the prons of that action and cons then the majority of the crew (and he is right sometimes). Team who kills a player for that, without watching his future actions are harming itself for sure.

That's why I said that on its own, it isn't griefing. But reading mage books without consulting anyone is often combined with suspicious actions, which often leads to the death of the person who read the book. I would say that most of the time, the person who read the book without consent is at fault for their death. It's an avoidable outcome on most ships.

In particular: People who read the mage book, then never use the skill. Most often, they are considered to be possible Mush, even if they're doing their jobs.

Or, those who read a book, and go completely inactive.

Or, people who never communicate, and thus wouldn't even bother explaining why they read it. These players also tend to not make use of the skill. The crew is forced to draw their own conclusions, and 80-90% of the time, the player is killed.

Or, people who wouldn't benefit from it immediately, because they already have a primary job to do. A Pilot shouldn't read a Biologist/Medic book, for example, unless there are plenty of other pilots, and there is a need for someone to switch roles to cover a gap in skills. It would make far less sense for a Paola to read a Pilot book, for example, unless Comms are done and she has Shooter; there are other candidates that are likely to have Shooter, and can use the book earlier in the voyage.

You can't always guarantee that the books will go to confirmed humans, but there ideally should be a discussion before they are read. Is it equally reasonable to argue that no mage books be read before all the Mush are dead? That depends on the crew. If you can finish your Mush hunt quickly, it's not so bad. If the hunt drags on more than a week, you could be shooting yourselves in the foot. The obvious compromise is to reserve the books for confirmed humans, and discuss it before they are read. That does nothing to prevent the confirmed humans from being victims of conversion or Transfer, much less assassination...but it does prevent people from being reported for playing against the team.
On august 24, 2014

On august 31, 2014
Dzanek

OK, let's start. My character: Paola. As I'm bronze, I pick nothing but Logistics Expert.
Crew activity: WOW! Half of gold players! Jin Su a pilot, shooter, leader and expert of logistics. Frieda 3 first skills, Kuan Ti everything except Optimist. Janice 4 first, Derek and Andie too, Eleesha 3 first. And Chun also 3 first skills. There was just one silver: Ian as Biologist with Green Thumb. Gioele picked Caffeine Junkie later and others with 1lvl skills but me. 4 morale support (the most possible without Mage Book and Stephen copying), 4 pilots, 2 astrophysicist, but 1 technician. And Raluca.

When Chun hadn't woken up, that crew was so awesome that I had to tell something, but in private:
Before Mush Selection, I predict myself to be a Mush.
Chun woke up. I was the Mush with Frieda on D1C7. It was sad that the Bridge is infected and I didn't see the real reason to go showering after extracting some spores, so I wasn't making them. Maybe building the sofa, but I must have 1 AP more. Sorry, one of crewmates decide to build the sofa for me. Andie built the sofa. So this voyage shouldn't go without infecting.

Gaining confidence was very easy. Just say what they want to hear. I did my work. In way to the Bridge I noticed in Central Corridor the Hacker Kit had been hidden, because Kuan Ti had dropped it and nobody picked up. Good to know.
At first night Raluca got killed because she held apron. I convinced Chun to kill Stephen and she expected him to be a Mush, because he stayed in Rear Corridor 3 cycles, I blamed him that he didn't claim one of rear turrets. He got killed the next night. And next night, Roland got killed because he was harmful. I was invited to Mush hunters channel. When I made some Xyloph, I wanted to be sure that Mage Book won't be printed as Technician skill. Jackpot! It was Medic and IT Expert. Chun told me that she had book of Pilot. She ordered me to hold Mage Book of IT Expert while she takes Medic.

Frieda was active just in cycles 2-3 and 6-7. In first 2 days she was gold, but the next days she'd become silver. But she could pretend to be innocent very well. Once she scanned and found an oxygen planet with Mankarog and Earthquake. Good mix for her Survivalist+Traitor. She continued scanning. She told in public that she found an oxygen planet with lots of steaks and fruit. I thought:
What has she done? They'll go to the clear oxygen planet instead of the dangerous one!
I wanted her to put some dangerous zones there, as the must go to that dangerous one. But she deleted that planet. So we should have convinced the crew to go to this "clear oxygen planet".
I went to Refectory to check if the Hacker Kit was still in the Central Corridor. Eleesha found it and took. It was bad. I noticed she went to the Bridge then and I thought she couldn't hold this Hacker Kit as human, I thought she hid it in the Front Corridor instead. If not, I should check Central Corridor and Bravo Bay.

I noticed there's half of crew in the Bravo Dorm, no cameras in Nexus and Lab, research wasn't going well so I seized the opportunity and told Chun that I'd noticed there's third Mush. I didn't want the crew to disclose us because nobody was infected. She believed me. I thought it'd be murder ship, but murders didn't happen quick.

My plan was that:
I'm saving my AP. While they'll be exploring this planet, I'll find this Hacker Kit. It must be in Front Corridor, Central Corridor or Bravo Bay. Go load fuel, read the mage book and hack into Command Terminal and leave orbit. There must be Jin Su and Andie, but if we're lucky, they'll be also Janice and Hua. After that, I'll go extract some spores, infect Kuan Ti and transfer into him. No technicians, no astrophysicist, no morale support and no pilots. This ship will be done.
But in practice, as always, something must be wrong. No the same people as I wanted? Yes, but the main trouble was Chun, who decided to hold the Hacker Kit. Exploring team: Eleesha, Janice, Jin Su, Hua, so almost perfect. It was cycle 6. I've already had a spore and stayed at the Bridge pretending to be dirty because of eating. I wanted to save some AP, because CS didn't allow to make the spore cheaply. Kuan Ti suspected me, but I believed nobody would kill me instantly because they trusted me, and if they decided to kill me, it'd be too late.

My plan must have been changed:
Frieda, please come back if you can. I need your help. I see you have a lot of AP saved. I'll kill Chun as Derek, then give you the Hacker Kit. You should read the Mage Book and leave orbit. I'll hide the Hacker Kit in <...> If you manage to do this or be too late, transfer into Kuan Ti. They shouldn't have any technician, he's the main target.
The rampage let's start. I checked rooms if Chun didn't trick us with Hacker Kit. It wasn't joke. I was a bit scared because both Chun and Derek were active a few minutes ago and they might move before my work will be done. My fail I didn't use all AP as Paola. I removed the camera in the Bravo Dorm and infected Derek. I wanted to pretend to be Beta, told in public:
Sorry crew, but they got me. They're really sneaky. I hate my team which convinced Chun to hold the Hacker Kit.
Transfered into Derek. I forgot to load the fuel. I had a blaster, and iTrakie. Took the scooter, loaded fuel, and went kill Chun. In the Medlab, picked Wrestler skill and hit Chun instead of using the Blaster I held. I killed Chun, 1 AP left. Dropped scooter and blaster, took Hacker Kit and Armor. Went at the Bridge, no AP. It was cycle change 6-7. Went sleep a bit. I had 2 AP, but it wasn't enough to hack into system. 10 minutes left and they'll go back. I hid the Hacker Kit.

And later, I got killed by Eleesha. She got Depression and proved she was human.
I watched this game, because I wasn't going to start the next one. They went to second expedition because she hadn't got oxygen. Expedition lasted 40 minutes, Frieda wasn't there. She was supposed to be there, but since I died, she hasn't been active. She went idling and got killed by Kuan Ti. If Frieda wasn't idling, this ship was gone, but now, my efforts are gone. Anyway good ship, no food-tests and played honestly.

On september 6, 2014
Vince
IsidarthChimeSo those Nova-things are also Glory bound? Didn't know.
Yup! It's just compared to the rest of the crew rather than a certain threshold, though. That's why it matters more than just flat Glory - useful crew members usually get more glory than less useful ones.

Not really the topic, I know, but... ouch. Please, don't teach this.


Glory, as such, does not necessarily equal usefulness. It ususally means that you were active, yes... but in fact, a player having the highest relative glory can mean that he did selfish and inefficient things just for that (like solving the cube, or shooting hunters from turrets) instead of actually helping the crew.

High flat glory, at least, means how successful your ships were in general. And for that it does take a functioning team, so that is something.

To get a golden Supernova on a long ship, however, you have to be Janice or a pilot. Period. Because the systems are unequal.


And to get the highest number of Supernovae... well.
You actually need your ships to fail early, while you are ahead (by picking someone who hits his peak early, like Roland) so you can "win" as many ships as possible.

I happened to get a streak of 5 consecutive Gold Awards at the start of this season, from 5 successful ships. You would think that is something... but not in the ranking. Because others had burned through 15 failships in the same time, which is apparently better.
Like Npfan said - and he has experience.


Long story short, don't overvalue glory. That would be a fail, if that led to your crew competing instead of cooperating, or trying to have the ship fail at an opportune time.
Have a fun game instead.

And I'm saying that as the current #1.
On september 6, 2014
npfan

For a long-term ship, it can't just be any pilot. That pilot has to be Hua.

VinceAnd to get the highest number of Supernovae... well.
You actually need your ships to fail early, while you are ahead (by picking someone who hits his peak early, like Roland) so you can "win" as many ships as possible.

You don't really need all of them to be fail ships, just quick ships. Last season, about a third to half of my ships reached Sol with no Mush.

On september 15, 2014
[8281990]

Chun was a newbie inactive - never talked, and Frieda totally called that she would starve to death on day 3. So she took it upon herself to keep the armor off the shelves.

The fail was in the paranoia of the crew. I personally had this elaborate scenario in my head where Frieda was a master social engineer mush, perhaps taunting Eleesha (who was already attracting crew ire for printing the list D2) in PM and letting her exhaust her AP trying to kill her, then play the angle of "oh my! I'm nearly beat to death and have an injury, let me take the medlab bed from the researchers for quite a few cycles!" Meanwhile, Gioele mush lamely rampages, and everyone exhausts their spare AP on him. Frieda gets dirty "from the surgery" and this persists across day change when we hadn't finished Constipaspore yet...

As it turned out, Eleesha was just bonkers, the AP need for the injury was completely real, the armor wasn't a cover for hardboiled, etc. You can see how the panic can get out of control, if you let it.

Dzanek

First time being Roland:
Day 1 - Went scavenging, went sleep.
Day 2 - Andie kicked me when I had 12 AP, I shouted at her, arguing and he/she became dirty and didn't want to take Bravo Dorm bed when free, so I did so and he/she said sorry to me then, while I was sleeping there. Once 2 hunter were outside, went to Refectory and took a ration, cooked it and then noticed Terrence dismantled Microwave, then knocked it out and pick it up, I thought he hid something, but found nothing, anyway I got dirty by cooking and shot just 1 hunter.
Day 3 - Hua infected someone in Lab (there were Stephen and Kuan Ti) and got caught because of MycoAlarm, she threw a grenade in Bravo Dorm, injuring me, crew killed her, I got gastroenterisis, I was staying in Alpha Dorm and asked crew for healing me. Hua wished us good luck with finding her partner.
Day 4 - Someone defaced logs in the Alpha Dorm. There were: Eleesha, Frieda and Roland lying down and Stephen staying, Jin Su went through Alpha Dorm cycle before defacing, and Raluca in the current cycle, and nobody healed me, so I went to Medlab and healed myself, curing gastroenterisis. I invited Ian, Andie and Janice as I trusted them, I told them that defacing was in order to turn someone into Mush, and there was Anynomush, Andie suspected me and blamed me that I did nothing after defacing and I was dirty. I told them that Frieda wouldn't be Alpha nor Beta Mush, because she hadn't visited Bravo Dorm and whole the time she was devoted scanning on the Bridge and returning to Alpha Dorm. Eleesha told Janice that Raluca visited Nexus, but I wouldn't suspect that Eleesha and Raluca are Mush, I excluded Raluca, but not Eleesha. I was arguing with them that Jin Su might have used defacer and it might have been cleared the next cycle. Andie noticed Jin Su was starving later, so I excluded him. I told them Eleesha and Stephen were Mush. Eleesha finished Hua's work and infected Stephen. A few cycle later, Stephen transferred into Janice and did nothing, just staying in Storage. We killed Janice, Stephen was alive. Whole time I was telling them Jin Su or Eleesha was Alpha Mush and said nothing about Stephen. They said that Eleesha, Frieda or Roland might have been Beta Mush. I told them Alpha Mush picked Anynomush, not Stephen because he was offline. I wanted to focus on Alpha Mush, arguing with Mush hunters, then Andie accused me Stephen was out of my suspicion and his rampage had happened because someone warned him. I told them if Eleesha said no Mush were there, she'd prove of being a Mush.
Day 5 - Eleesha told us no Mush was there. I didn't trust her, I was 100% sure she was a Mush, but I was arguing with crew. I wanted to kill her, but Ian said "Stop killing, no Mush, no murder". I was sure she lied. I wanted to refill my AP and kill Eleesha, but after arguing I changed my mind and ordered them to make RFS, but it was hard. Andie was just a pilot, Ian was the only biologist, Chun was holding apron as inactive. They agreed with me. They wanted to wait until she starves. Anyway, I ordered Raluca to report if Eleesha visits her, and to stop making PILGRED until RFS is done.


Questions:
How did I die? We went on expo, Eleesha took Hacker Kit which left in Alpha Dorm and and left us to die, 5 of us died at once.
Why didn't I kill Eleesha? Because Ian was arguing with me, Stephen and Andie thought the Mush was gone, and threated me of death if I attempted to kill Eleesha. Derek told he would kill Eleesha if they agreed with me, but they didn't. Also, I was scared that SDF would give me some points.
Why didn't I hide the Hacker Kit? Because I was still suspicious by Andie and I thought I'd die if I attempted to hide it. I ordered my team to hide it, but they didn't listen to me.
How did I find out Stephen was Beta Mush? - He made a lot of relays with research, made ASG and MA. He also copied Janice's "Shrink" skill and comforted her. I wouldn't believe that the same person was so expienced to use defacer, and so newbie to make a rampage with no innocent victims there.

Eleesha and Hua, say thanks to:
Andie - He/She was accusing me, threated to kill me whoel the time, even if I was sick, even after Stephen's die (I wouldn't say how when Eleesha said no Mush was there). He/She always said I was wrong, argued with me. He/She always turned us to wrong way.
Ian - Altrough he was 4lvl gold player, he also turned us to wrong way. He acted to be confused and after Mush were gone, he said nothing about suspects. He mainly prevented me from killing Eleesha.
Jin Su - He ordered us to make Mushicide Soap, above than Pheromodem and RFS. He took the soap to Lab just because there was Cristalite zone on the planet we were going to expo, he didn't listen to me when I told several times that Ian is Mycologist and removes spores while healing, and he'd heal us after expo.
Raluca - Even if she was full efficient gold player, she used her genius skill for Plasma Shield, when it was easy to make as Technician+Physicist, supported by Designer. She told she wouldn't take that risk, because Mush would make another project and skip Plasma Shield. When I asked how difficult another projects were to do (base efficiency), she didn't even look at it. If she wouldn't use it for Plasma Shield, she'd make RFS and we would have Eleesha as human. I considered her as our last hope to make RFS while Chun was holding apron and Ian couldn't make it.
Chun - she went inactive with apron, if she didn't take it, we'd probably make RFS.

Even if Eleesha does his work and shares Tracker skill, and helps a bit with research and projects, don't be blind. Her IT Points are used instead of AP, and she nicely helps with research while no camera is being there. Of course helps to infect Stephen.

On september 27, 2014
[7950824]

It can take some time to figure out how to win as a mush.

I'm not saying that your two, Vince, are newish, should be forgiven, or even that they did no wrong, but my first time as alpha mush I created this plan that seemed like it might work, and should get Chun and Janice dead; Ian being by Janice ruined the plan so I ran off to kill 'someone', anyone else I could, whomever seemed the most useful to take out that wasn't hidden by Ian.

I ended up in a dorm with three pilot choices; Highly active Jin who I knew was very low AP, Hua who I knew was no AP, and Roland who I figured was very high AP, so I reasoned that taking him out would be best, at least short term, maybe I could live long enough to do more damage after.

I did manage to kill Roland, and cycle change finished 0 morale Chun off.... And it was as I was writing a note to my partner, to explain and wish them luck that I remembered.... Roland was my partner. In my stress and excitement, and inexperience, I totally forgot who my partner was and never, ever thought to recheck; I never even considered that I could possibly kill my partner; I wasn't even thinking as I rushed to pick a target that I had a partner. Sure, I 'knew', but totally not in my awareness with all the rest of the adrenal rush.

Sooooo. Being mush can be pretty stressful, and intense, and you can be a decent human-side player and an utter klutz when it comes to being a mush. I haven't looked at what happened on that ship, but there's a chance at least that this ship's mush are still finding their spore-legs. Meet them again after a year's play, and they might just rock your socks off.

Vince

Better yet! The fail does not end there.

To start, this was a ship with ideal Mush conditions, short of one that would fail even without Mush:
Very slow filling, average crew, no research done until way into D3. Game started D2C8, about 2 hours before day change.

So the Mush immediately had access to 8 spores, Chun was not armored (Janice was), and blasters were still lying around. Enough to do terrible damage with Phagocyte alone.

But this was not just any Mush. He was a Gold mode, with access to Mycellum (for 10 spores), Fertile, Transfer, Defacer, Infector... you name it. Horrid!

But yeah, his tactic of choice was to light fires. And hide the extinguishers. Both of them... in FC and RC, where they had been all along! Did not even pick them up first to make us think he moved them.

Also, he would not have needed to possess Roland. - He was the NERON Admin! Twice, in fact: As Terrence before transferring into Jancie, and then again, 5 minutes later, when his activity brought the title back to her on cycle change.

So... yeah.

Gallade

What counts as surrender, though?
Does, as a Mush, not fighting back/going to the Lab when humans spotted you and are about to finish RFS count?
Does, as a human, going back to Sol with a single Mush on board because the alternative is getting destroyed by asteroids count?
On october 10, 2014
NERON

Even if you're found out, you need to make an effort to still hurt the humans as much as you can. Possibly getting yourself killed in the process. But it must further the mush cause. Going to the lab to get serum'd is against the rules.

If you're human and know 100% there's still mush, returning to Sol will make your team lose 100%. If you stick around, there''s always the chance something saves you. Someone could kill the mush in a last ditch effort without regard for accidentally killing a human. The game might bug out and skip hunter damage for the next cycle. A pilot might come online and shoot the asteroid. Your crew can also shoot the asteroid from turrets.
On october 10, 2014
[7950824]

The question of 'what counts as surrender' boils down to a judgment call, did the player reasonably do the best they could to try and get a win for their side under the circumstances.

A human going back to sol with any living mush, from 1 to everyone else on the ship is a human that acts to create a human loss. If that human clearly knows, from what happens on that ship, that are live mush on board, and does not act to kill those mush before attempting to go back to Sol, yes, that human is clearly surrendering.

Yes it is wrong to surrender. You can be sanctioned for suicide if you are reported on a ship one cycle from destruction, because you picked up and dropped an object until random hurting yourself killed you. If that's your situation, that you have no options to save the ship, still wait. Maybe a shipmate can find an answer. Maybe you and your shipmates together can find the answer. Leaping into death earlier is nothing but pathetic suicide, and that's the name of the sanction you'd probably get if you did so.

Returning to Sol under safe conditions, when the ship appears well able to continue longer and without consent from the rest of the crew is widely viewed by the SDF as being a form of suicide that also kills the rest of the ship, and this is called 'harmful return to Sol'.

Returning to Sol under conditions of having known living mush, knowingly causing the game to end with a mush win while playing a human, that's at least as wrong as a 'harmful return to Sol' and clearly fits within that restriction.

Even if the ship is a cycle from destruction, one of your shipmates might have the answer you don't seem to have, to get that mush dead so the ship can leap to Sol with a human win. But embracing, creating the win for the enemy side, that's absolutely wrong and it removes any hope of a win for your side.

As to the mush, exposed, going meekly to the lab where the serum nears completion, that's harder to rule. I could see myself doing that, with full intention of refreshing like a maniac, grabbing the serum, and using it on a human before they could grab and use it on me.... or trying to time a transfer or something. Wouldn't be my first pick of strategy, but if that exact ship seemed perfect for it, I definitely would consider it. But you can bet I'd create a PM before I went to the lab, and I'd be explaining to myself, for the judges' eyes later, what I intended and why I thought that was the best way to work towards a mush win in my exact circumstances. Sure, if I -look- like I'm playing to lose, I expect to be reported, and if that play could cause me to lose despite a chance to win... wow did I pick a risky path. I might get sanctioned, and I'd talk to the other mods about it, but I'd expect to have a real chance to need to keep that sanction. You have to be extremely careful with anything that even looks like surrender or suicide, and the more it looks like it, the more likely you are to be sanctioned for it, period.

So I would only consider taking that action if I felt it was actually the very best path towards a mush win for my exact circumstances, because in doing so I'm walking the edge of appearing to break the rules, and if my plan fails, it looks exactly like I intended to break the rules.... And if it looks exactly like I intended to break the rules, then.... I really can't say that I didn't deserve the sanction. If I make a plan that looks like I'm trying to lose, and I lose.... I should have known to not make that plan in the first place.
On october 10, 2014

On october 11, 2014
[8356287]
Impet

As to the mush, exposed, going meekly to the lab where the serum nears completion, that's harder to rule. I could see myself doing that, with full intention of refreshing like a maniac, grabbing the serum, and using it on a human before they could grab and use it on me.... or trying to time a transfer or something. Wouldn't be my first pick of strategy, but if that exact ship seemed perfect for it, I definitely would consider it. But you can bet I'd create a PM before I went to the lab, and I'd be explaining to myself, for the judges' eyes later, what I intended and why I thought that was the best way to work towards a mush win in my exact circumstances. Sure, if I -look- like I'm playing to lose, I expect to be reported, and if that play could cause me to lose despite a chance to win... wow did I pick a risky path. I might get sanctioned, and I'd talk to the other mods about it, but I'd expect to have a real chance to need to keep that sanction. You have to be extremely careful with anything that even looks like surrender or suicide, and the more it looks like it, the more likely you are to be sanctioned for it, period.

So I would only consider taking that action if I felt it was actually the very best path towards a mush win for my exact circumstances, because in doing so I'm walking the edge of appearing to break the rules, and if my plan fails, it looks exactly like I intended to break the rules.... And if it looks exactly like I intended to break the rules, then.... I really can't say that I didn't deserve the sanction. If I make a plan that looks like I'm trying to lose, and I lose.... I should have known to not make that plan in the first place.


"Looks like" an intention to break the rules...

Is that really the criteria for final verdict of a sanction?

In the given example, the only questionable action was to enter the Lab while RFS was nearing completion. As you point out, there are several strategic reasons for doing so - maybe not the best strategies, but legitimate enough. The fact that it's also very risky shouldn't necessarily make this a sanctionable action, IMHO.

As I see it, the key is knowing the player's intention. If the player expressed a desire to be cured, then that's an obvious violation. But when the player's intent cannot be clearly determined, I would think they should be given the benefit of the doubt.

Many actions are risky in some way. That's part of the fun and the learning process. If I take a gamble in-character, and it fails, then that failure is my punishment for choosing a poor strategy, so I'll learn a lesson from it.

But if I need to worry about whether a particular action might be misinterpreted somehow, such that I, as a player, could face a serious consequence for a poor decision I've made in good faith for my character and my team, then that would create a harmful "chilling effect" that would influence my IC decisions with this OOC paranoia.

A player should never feel the need to preemptively explain their intentions to the judges in fear of being sanctioned for taking a legitimate risk in-character. If there is any possible interpretation that the player might have had a good reason to take that risk, and there is no conclusive proof that the player intended to break the rules, then the player should not be punished for the appearance that they might have been trying to break the rules.

But maybe I don't fully understand how the policy is applied, or the rationale behind it. I'm sure there are many cases that are very difficult to judge, and many factors that must be balanced to keep the game enjoyable.


In the larger view, a Mush who gives up is a player who obviously didn't want to be Mush. Likewise, I suspect that some griefer behavior may be due to an unfulfilled desire to play as Mush.

I would expect to see both problems reduced if players had some degree of choice in the matter. What would be the harm in that? Why force players onto a team they don't want to play for?

Consider an option under the My Account > My Settings page:

Alpha Mush Selection:

  • Yes, I hope to be selected as an Alpha Mush
  • No, I'd prefer not to be selected as an Alpha Mush
  • I'm happy either way - surprise me! [default]

The actual selection would still be random, but partially adjusted or "filtered" by this preference.

Alternatively (or perhaps additionally), a similar adjustment could be made by Judges. Instead of giving warnings, quarantines, suspensions and terminations for playing against the team, Judges could reduce the likelihood that a player will be on that particular team in the future. For example, take away "Mush privileges" from players who try to get cured, or take away "Human privileges" for players who rampage as Humans.

Have any solutions like these ever been attempted?
On october 11, 2014
[8356287]

On october 12, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieI want people to like me as I am, and trust me although I say different things.
I don't want people to trust me just because I did "food-test" or what else. If they wanted to kill me because I wanted burn my Technician Points to repair the door and accidently got dirty, and after I healed them 4 times (8AP), it's their problem, not mine now.
I felt arkward amongst people who take pill and ration with non-sense, and investigate badly.

You DO realize that the things you say - and the way you say them - can make you seem untrustworthy, don't you? The actions you take and the attitude you bring to the ship are as much of a factor in whether people trust you as any test of humanity. If they don't think they can rely on you to do what is needed, they can and will kill you, regardless of whether you're a confirmed human.

Telling them, "If you think I'm Mush, then kill me" as part of any response is also potentially sanctionable; it escalates the situation, and wastes AP if they go through with it. What you're saying is, "It's your fault you killed me, when I dared you to kill me." Do not do that.

You want people to like you? Then don't antagonize them. You want people to trust you? Then don't take suspicious actions, and then play the victim card when people become suspicious of you. Also, don't accuse confirmed humans, unless you have evidence of griefing. It makes people suspect you even more.

On october 13, 2014
CraZy-gAEmeR

There are still too many problems with... well... everything!

The most known one being the tutorial.

There's also the problem about "Sanctioning someone for surrendering." As said, people do risky things because it helps them learn and could do a great deal to help their team. However, these can be seen as surrendering, which could make people not do them, which means their team could lose because they were influenced into not doing something by OOC things.

The response to this is that they could state their reasons for why they're doing it, to make their intentions known. However, they could also lie about this, saying that they are attempting to do something with the intention of actually surrendering, so there's no way this should work.

I think we should do that idea of being able to increase the odds of you being Mush or Human. People can say it's a bad idea but from what I've seen, it's also a bad idea to leave this as it is, increasing the chances of surrendering Mush or rampaging Humans. It seems like the most beneficial thing would be to atleast try it.

You have lost 6 hp. 14min
You don't feel very good, not good at all... Hot... Cold... Hot... Cold... You should see a doctor. You have contracted a physiological disease: Quinck's Oedema. 14min
You have been hurt: Burnt arms. This will incur penalties. 14min
Raluca is experiencing a violent cutaneous eruption, they are choking. However, we may have told them that it was nothing to do with that #+ of a cat! 14min
Raluca has picked up the Schrdinger. 14min
From 16 hp to 5 hp, and all actions cost +2ap now. At least 6 ap to do self-surgery. And need at least 2 heals with medkit to restore hp and cure 2 illness.

That Cat Allergy is more cruel, then 3 blaster shoots.

How do you tell a hopeless rampage from a hopeful (?) one?
On october 18, 2014
[7937939]

Hopeless rampage: No weapons, no grenade, fists of paper. 1 or 2 mush present with 1 or 2 casualties.
Hopeful rampage: Weapons galore (mmm build that rocket launcher), 2+ mush with very high human casualties.
Is that what you're looking for?

On october 18, 2014
[7937939]

The true difference between a good rampage and a not so good one would be the outcome. If you take out one key member and completely cripple the ship (like killing the only tech making PILGRED extremely hard) then that would be more of a success then just killing say Janice and they finish PILGRED the next day. As an evil mushroom it is your role to bring devastation to the enemy team, and how you do that is entirely up to you.
On october 18, 2014

On october 18, 2014
Kyubey

Rampages scales from of their outcome of the game.
Humans team lost - then it was good rampage. Humans returned to Sol (even with few members alive, even without cure) - bad rampage then. Just using tons of weapons and taking 5-6 humans does not means you did good, sometimes even one kill is enough.
Hopeless rampage - when any human watching your rampage can say after killing you - ha, we will survive this easily and now there are no mushes to worry about.
On october 18, 2014
Misterme7

On october 18, 2014
[7950824]

There's two classes of rampages - those that have already happened, and those that you are preparing to do. You can never know the effect of your rampage until after the fact, but you can know it's potential. I would call a 2 grenade rampage backed up with blaster and knife (and presumably high AP) to be a very hopeful rampage regardless of the outcome, even if your grenades both happen to do 1 point of damage to all humans and 3 points to you, the first shot with the blaster separated your shoulder, and the first stab with the knife gave you a perforated lung. That's a rampage that is worthy of the fail thread.... but not from the preparation. That rampage could have easily killed every human present with the two grenades then several more elsewhere from the weapons. It's all in the dice: That's the hope. But some mush rampages are planned to be hopeless. Here's a fantastic example of that:

One of my ships had two alpha mush who were acting fairly human; the Janice was being somewhat difficult and slow, and her AP spending was minimal. The mushhunt team identified her as an extremely likely mush, but we had cameras and mycoalarms all over the place, no one had spores, roomlogs suggested no one had much chance to get any spores, and we decided to try and kill her partner and cure her if we could, but we had no idea who her partner was, except that Eleesha, a total newbie who then went inactive had printed the list day 1. Janice's name wasn't on it, but around 5 players were who were all acting very human but were not proven either way as yet.

The first death came from a player not on the list becoming quarantined, and they died human. This was noted at the time in the mushhunt channel, then moments later Janice was asking if a mush was dead, because a mush was gone; and amusingly, one of the mush had taken anonymush. Janice? Probably, she sure was the one talking about it. We of the mush hunt thread kind of stared at each other and discussed how and if to use 'falling for this ploy' in what we did about it; and immediately after Roland, on Eleesha's list and not part of the mushhunt thread, talked about how great it was that a mush was dead.

Now, if you hover your mouse over the crewbar, it tells you the dead player is human. Dead humans have a different colored icon than dead mush, and even if you ignore those things, dead humans don't unlock the research that dead mush do.... research that almost all ships rush to start very soon after mush death. If we're going to 'fall for the ploy', it's going to have to be brief, because so much reveals it is false... We are discussing this and what we are going to do about it, and making the decision to kill Roland or not (evidence of his supporting her ploy is good enough that he is her partner? Could any human be fooled by so obvious a lie, really? Surely that's her partner supporting her claim) and wondering what she would do, if we had time to kill Roland and still make the cure to stick her without her realizing she was caught too (how can we believe Roland was mush supporting the lie without believing Janice who started it was mush?)

As we discuss, Hua, also on Eleesha's list, suddenly makes a spore on camera and attacks a person in that room with just two punches, then grabs an extinguisher and a couple other things and posts that she's going to take off in the Pasiphae, then moves to AB2. She doesn't immediately take off (we don't have net) and people are able to run and kill her. She makes a post about how pathetic her rampage is, how she's even laughing at herself, and she dies mush.

So now we have a dead mush for real; and Janice exults about how both mush are dead, lets get to Eden. We of the mush hunt channel support the lie and make plans to rush the cure (both to make sure Janice doesn't have time to catch us not believing the lie, and to make sure that people playing like all the mush are dead doesn't give Janice a chance to jump to sol or infect anyone else) and she gets cured soon after.

But that plan by Hua's, pretty clearly done to try and 'look real', but appearing to try and make sure not to actually damage the ship at all (giving it the best chance to reach Eden with mush aboard?) - that's a clear 'hopeless rampage'; Two punches cannot kill anyone who isn't almost dead, and that was the extent of the rampage. It had no hope from the outset, and not even luck could have made it be 'effective'. Of course, her goal probably was not to be effective, and hope her team without her made it to Eden or at least Sol.

I totally do not recommend this sort of ploy, by the way. It can fool newbies, but it's not a great idea to fool newbies, and if you have even 1 experienced player on your ship who is paying adequate attention, the ship knows it isn't mush free.
On october 18, 2014

On october 19, 2014
[7950824]

A ship with a mod on it is -exactly- like every other ship in play and if we have to deal with a griefer or any other sort of rulebreaker with the rest of our ship, we do just like every other player does - we report them. handle it in play with the rest of our shipmates, and wait for the report process to handle it some time after the end of that ship. We don't even participate in judging our own ships

As to that Hua, no, I didn't talk to them (unless you mean indirectly, from them reading the forum). Hua appeared to try a high risk strategy with her partner; if it had worked it may well have gotten her partner alive to Sol or even Eden.

I disapprove of how high risk it was but that's me as a player and strategist speaking, not me as a mod saying 'this is the rule that must be enforced'. I personally don't think, in that circumstance, that Hua broke any rules. I even know that no newbies were misled (for long) on that ship, because after the ruse was dealt with the whole thing was explained on the ship, and how to tell that it was a trick. But I didn't report Hua and I don't even know if anyone else did (I was on the ship, I wouldn't be involved in judging the case anyway).

Now, if a player without the appearance of a mush team plan that can use a weak rampage were to rampage that weakly... Yes, I probably would report the player for pathetic suicide as mush. But that's not what I saw on my ship.

Your attempt to win does not have to succeed. Your attempt to win may have some serious flaws with it. But you need to attempt to win. If you do, that's legal play (as long as it doesn't break other rules).
On october 20, 2014
Vince

That is the point: Attempting to win. It's all about the spirit.

Of course there is a large grey area of attempts just failing, and I expect that the mods are very lenient in that regard. As they should be, because you want the Mush to try crazy stuff at times.

But there is also a point where it is obvious that somebody did not even try, and instead just threw the game for some selfish reason.

Don't be that guy. You could be surprised how fun it can be to fight -and maybe win against all odds- an uphill battle.
On october 20, 2014
Gargaron

Indeed, I always take the view that if the Mush has a plan with a 50% chance of success that will lead to a fun and exciting adventure, or a plan with 75% chance of success that will basically be boring whether it works or not, they should go for the first!

I also have an innate preference for infection above rampaging, because infection makes more of a game of it.
On october 20, 2014
Gargaron

Hard to tell the chances of success anyway. This game continually amazes me because humans tend to be completely paranoid about the actions and intentions of the mush, and yet when you do take a risk as mush, what you can often get away with is incredible.

(The paranoia works both ways - as mush I tend to assume I am monitored more closely than I really am, and I probably devote a little too many resources to acting human. But then again, I don't know the times when that has saved me by causing suspicion to fall on someone else...)

On october 22, 2014
[7950824]

Hey NGJon. Sounds like you're having a rough 4th ship.

Based purely what you've said in the forum, sounds like there's a bit of confusion and some rules getting bent if not broken on your ship. Yes, we greatly frown upon people surrendering or suiciding, however we also greatly frown upon players creating a hostile environment for other players, be that through personal attacks or any other way that one can harass or bully others.

Now, I don't know what is happening on your ship; I'm not on it, and I can't view it under present circumstances.

Someone telling you to 'go die' can potentially be breaking Terms & Conditions(T&C; http://support.twinoid.com/cgu); part of what we agree to when we create our Twinoid accounts is that we will engage in good conduct in every way in which we interact with others (Games, forum, PM.. all areas of exchange), and specifically agree not to insult others; we also agree not to encourage suicide, which 'go die' would directly violate.

What I'd like you to do is create a report on each person who you believe may be breaking the game rules, which includes terms and conditions, so that the SDF (volunteer players selected to help enforce the rules in a specific and constrained fashion) will be able to review the ship and pass judgment as deserved, from 'cleared' to sanctioned. There is no harm for anyone in reporting behavior which appears to break the rules. If you're wrong and the person is not breaking the rules, they don't get punished. If you make a report that seems to the judges to be utterly senseless, utterly baseless, you could be warned for it, but if there is any question as to it maybe making sense why you report something, that's not going to happen. From what you've said, this behavior should be reported.

What the person on your ship said about a 27 day quarantine is utter hogwash, in terms of reality. We have a report process, and the person reporting you has no say in your judgment or sanction, even if they are a judge. Other judges, not that one, would handle the case. No member of SDF would discuss the details of a sanction - and we do not encourage anyone else to do so. Posts have been deleted by moderators for discussing details of sanctions, and we don't discuss them on ships either. Please do not view what that person said as having any basis in the reality you are actually going to experience.

But we only 'get' to judge behavior that is reported. No matter how much we want to jump in without a report. So do yourself a favor, and everyone else who may ever play beside a rulebreaker a favor, and make judges and mods smile - we are volunteers, we actually want to judge cases that need judging - allow the SDF to evaluate questionable or worse behavior, by reporting it. Make sure you report the character making the comments or taking the actions, and report each person separately who appears to be breaking rules.

On october 23, 2014
npfan
ImpetSomeone telling you to 'go die' can potentially be breaking Terms & Conditions(T&C; http://support.twinoid.com/cgu); part of what we agree to when we create our Twinoid accounts is that we will engage in good conduct in every way in which we interact with others (Games, forum, PM.. all areas of exchange), and specifically agree not to insult others; we also agree not to encourage suicide, which 'go die' would directly violate.

For clarification, telling someone to 'go die' would only break T&C if it was encouraging real-life suicide. Seriously encouraging someone to commit suicide in the game is against the SDF rules. Also, insulting is allowed on an RP-level (e.g. Damn you dirty Mush!), but personal attacks also goes against game rules.
On october 23, 2014

On october 23, 2014
[7950824]
GalladeI actually managed to eject just before they moved the ship, thus losing the Sample and Apron forever. Goodbye research, hello dirtiness.

That's a valid strategy, in that there's no rule against it.

I recommend that you watch the outcome of the ship though.

Does your side win?

If you continue to use this strategy when mush, keep on keeping track. Sure, you can 'do' it; you can do any strategy. This one happens to be lethal to you, which can make it easy to walk away with a mission accomplished feel.

That's a great feeling.

But was what you achieved your actual goal? Does this strategy, combined with whatever else was happening, form part of your team winning and the humans losing?

If the humans manage to return to Sol without living mush - you lost. No two ways about it.

Sure, use this strategy. Verify if it usually works or not. Refine it, improve it, make it more and more effective - if it's a winning or nearly winning strat.

However.

If you find that most of the ships you 'achieve' this on go on to be human wins....

I trust that you, and others, are players who want to be skilled players. You want to play for your team to win, be that team mush or human. We all lose, as mush and humans, but hopefully we all learn from our wins and losses.

If you find that most of the ships that you do this too achieve human wins, you're not actually doing great, you're being a 'pest' instead of a conqueror. If that is what happens, then you're letting your team down, not building them up, and you've eliminated a portion of your team, thus some significant refining of the strategy might be wise.

Or, if you find that the plan you and your partner(s) make, with this being part of it, is effective at getting mush wins.... glory in that too.

Don't cut yourself short. Be proud that you beat the humans using this method or any other, not that you annoyed them at the cost of your own life.

On october 29, 2014
[7950824]

You don't ask any questions in this, so I assume you're trying to ask a general 'is this alright? What should I do if anything?' about the situation.

For you, if you think you see evidence that the player betrayed their team by giving up, trying to help humans defeat the mush (note it is NOT wrong for a mush to help humans without revealing themselves as mush - and often that help is necessary to further the mush plan until it is time to strike, or sneak alive to Sol or Eden; a perfectly valid way for mush to win) - if you think that player was trying to lose or breaking any other game rules, please report them. If you don't think you see evidence that the player was breaking game rules, please don't report them.

The SDF does not care if you are right in what you think you see - if it looks like rulebreaking, please report it. People who report for really bad reasons, or lie about the reasons they are reporting about (like, a report from Paola claiming "Jin said he and Eleesha were the mush team!" when Jin did not say that or anything like that during the course of the ship) probably face an 'abusive report' sanction for making a false report, but if we can see why a reporter might think something could be breaking the rules, we do not punish reporters. If we don't find evidence that a rule was broken, we don't punish the people who were reported.

If it looks like the Mush player had or even may have had a strategy that could have helped their team and was taking action on it, but failed and died through being foiled or through bad luck, we don't sanction that player. Players are not required to be successful, but they are required to try.

If you report any player, after the ship is over the report will become visible to the judges, who will review the report and the evidence in the ship logs and will independently vote on what level of sanction they feel is appropriate, from 'cleared' if they feel the player is innocent to whatever level of sanction for the rulebreaking they identified.

Eleesha : Okay, the coffee delivered. Let's kick his assEleesha rate son coup sur Jin Su.
Eleesha tente de frapper Jin Su, hlas son coup faible trouve seulement le mur... Ae...
Eleesha met une droite Jin Su
Eleesha rate son coup sur Jin Su.Eleesha : Okay, torture him right now
Chao : Chao s'en prend violemment Jin Su. Il attrape un annuaire qui trainait par l et lui mets de grand coups avec... C'est sanguinolent, mais Jin Su finit par parler... Sa dernire action est S'allonger.
Eleesha : What the hell does it mean
Chao : It means I wasted AP torturing him at full
Chao : Did you miss hitting him twice?
Chao : Ok, according to google translate, you hit him once for 1
Eleesha : Oh wow, I'm such a good fighter Eleesha tente de frapper Jin Su, hlas son coup faible trouve seulement le mur... Ae...

Eleesha mets un magistral uppercut Jin Su...Chao : Google translate says you hit him once more. Now he is missing 3-5

I had been thinking that either of our last two to awaken - Kuan Ti or Hua - were our Mush, since they were one of the small list of people who could have Green Jellied the Research Terminal (which could have broken randomly, but unlikely). Deciding to check it out after cycle change, I notice logs of Kuan Ti taking the Armour, Wrench and an Extinguisher from Rear Corridor. Seems I was right on the third count, and sure enough the Extinguisher has been Dismantled (with one hidden elsewhere) and I see him and Raluca standing there skill-less. What I didn't see were logs of Kuan Ti dropping the Armour to pick it up as Raluca, just logs of a lot of failed punches by the new Raluca. Small setup:
I was Jin Su, who"talked" in gestures and not at public-channel until a single time the Brainsync was established; didn't prevent me helping relaying research and establishing comm.-links, to name minor examples.
Unfortunately the crew was in overall quite "super-meta" alongside not-so-active, even if there was a lot of research done and hunters being kept under control, what little of them there was (even I took down three of them at one point).
Aside the non-talking "inactive" and the lovely "power of love"-person (no sarcasm intended), a large portion of the crew was downright hostile to "everyone"...

The fail itself:
After finally someone else stepped in to replace inactivity + false-info-tactic using mush-astrophysicist and gave coordinates, I went and changed to heading to be correct. Then I started actively monitor-waiting for someone to put in the fuel to combustion-chamber.
Suddenly a technician rushes in and blasts the mush into smithereens; good, I suppose...
Then he punches me to death: I only had 6HP-left due double steel-plated on the very same day...

I didn't mention we only had a single unit of O2 on that same cycle, did I?..

((Yes, I did write a Neuron Root Journal of this trip.))

But I say at least to my own defence: I did all I could, and you had no evidence to justify your slaughter alongside all evidence found tells I did actually work...

On december 4, 2014
Pave

The "Like"-buttons aren't all that intuitive / buggy to begin with: I've personally had to re-click a number times before they either activated or they for some other reason have a huge delay.
They not necessarily wouldn't need to be "check-boxes" due the possible script-exploitations and such, but they certainly should be "less-delayed" and giving more "feedback" than they currently do.

So yeah, it's highly likely that players clicking the "Like-buttons" think the "Like" has seen sent & received when in reality the button hasn't even registered the click (not to mention the difference / color-look between "activated-like" and "inactive"-buttons is very unnoticeable on higher-resolution-screen where the buttons become quite tiny).
On december 4, 2014
[8147734]
PaveThe "Like"-buttons aren't all that intuitive / buggy to begin with: I've personally had to re-click a number times before they either activated or they for some other reason have a huge delay.

Seconding this.

On a few occasions Ive been unable to get them to work at all and ended up not giving out any. I tried changing browsers/computers but for whatever reason it wouldnt work at all.
On december 4, 2014
[8356287]

I agree it's confusing and a bit frustrating without immediate feedback, but they do register each click. You don't have to wait for the UI to respond each time - you can quickly Like the whole crew in just a couple of seconds.

If you click the button a second time, it will UNDO your Like. That may be the reason why they seem to not respond sometimes. Because without immediate feedback, many people do click again, but this actually creates the problem they were trying to solve. When the UI finally updates, it has responded to both clicks, and the end result is the same as if you had never clicked at all.

So just ignore the feedback (or lack thereof) and click each button ONE time for each person you like. Then it's quick and reliable.
On december 4, 2014
Addem-Up

I did that. It didn't register any likes I'd submitted after the first one had begun loading.
On december 4, 2014
CraZy-gAEmeR

I actually click them 3 times. It's probably better than clicking once and hoping that it worked.
On december 4, 2014
illios10

I just click it very often very fast and wait until it changes it colour. Works perfectly fine. There's so many problems solved by rapidly clicking.

On december 4, 2014
[8356287]
Addem-UpI did that. It didn't register any likes I'd submitted after the first one had begun loading.

I'm curious about 2 things:
1. What browser were you using?
2. How careful were your observations?

A valid test would be to write down the number of Likes for the whole crew before clicking anything. Then after clicking all the desired Likes (ONE time each), wait for at least a full minute before comparing the "after" numbers to the "before" numbers. (I definitely wouldn't rely on the "Loading" indicator.)


CraZy-gAEmeRI actually click them 3 times. It's probably better than clicking once and hoping that it worked.

"Yes-no-yes" equals "Yes."

You might as well click them 7 times each. "Yes-no-yes-no-yes-no-yes" still equals "Yes."


illios10I just click it very often very fast and wait until it changes it colour. Works perfectly fine. There's so many problems solved by rapidly clicking.

You click an indeterminate number of times? And then you rely on the first moment when it seems to respond? But there would still be an indeterminate number of clicks that it hasn't yet processed at that point. So the result would be indeterminate, like a coin-toss.

That gives me the heebie-jeebies.

On december 4, 2014

I was using Google Chrome. I was paying very careful attention; the ship had just finished d10, and I had many likes to give.

[7950824]

Issue is more, Flooding is against the rules. It's not playing to help your team, it's not even really playing. Think about what the roomlog must look like in that room, for a player walking into it. Think about the extra work and loading for that specific game, the possible extra lag that game has affecting all the players on it.

If I had to judge that ship, I definitely could. I could sort through that spam.

The issue is, I'd be annoyed. Deeply annoyed. That's a huge, huge flood. and maybe other rules broken too. By the time I was done and ready to pass sentence.... what kind of sentence do you expect to be passed?

Do you really want judges and mods to be -annoyed- while they consider the evidence of your guilt or innocence and are deciding what punishment your crimes deserve?

On december 6, 2014
noso

This was a technical win, but feels more like failure so I'll put it here.

I was Ian on a ship that got a tough start from a good mush play: (silver level 15 alpha-mush) Gioele hijacked our Chun's radio early on and fingered Andie, then quickly killed her. Our quasi-griefer Kuan Ti lost his marbles and immediately attacked Chun, nearly killing her; she came to me for healing and pacifism (& morale). This led the crew to confabulate an elaborate theory of transfer from Kuan Ti to Gioele, and Gioele was rightfully killed for the wrong reason. I'm still new to the game and didn't clue in to the radio pirate until Chun figured it out and repaired her walkie talkie.

So I kept gardening and researching, because nothing else really helps in a dysfunctional world (something you can also eventually learn IRL). Having no biologist was a setback but Chun and I relayed with help from Roland and Hua, and we made decent progress on Constipaspore and Antispore. The remaining alpha-mush (gold level 13 Terrence) communed with his Mycelium Spirit and made Fertile spores - with my name on them.

Eleesha and I relayed on NCC Lenses and completed them. I realised too late that the cat was probably infectious: Eleesha got one scratch, and I had two in total from lens research (newbie mistake #1). We made the Mushovore Bacteria and were close to Mycoalarms, but still some way from Mycoscan. I wanted that because I felt by this point that I was spored at least once, and Eleesha too. I was correct.

Meanwhile we didn't have great leadership coordination (sorry Jin Su, you did try later on), repeatedly failed to kill hunters or jump away from them or patch the hull, and the ship was getting close to destruction. Chun and I were split between the Lab and Medlab (newbie mistake #2) when Terrence made his move: he double-spiked me at day change and complimented me as the "most adequate human" for him to convert, mainly because I was actively communicating on a pretty taciturn crew. The world became simple and clear with my new mission, and Terrence went anonymush. No one the wiser as far as I knew, but Terrence had left some suspicious tracks on the room log and I knew our Eleesha would notice them eventually.

Jin Su remarked that we were in rough shape and would have to kill the remaining mush, fix Pilgred, and jump back to Sol. We'd soon be destroyed by hunters anyway unless we could load fuel every cycle, but weak command communication meant no one was apparently active and with enough movement points to get there and do it. I say apparently, because I could have done it, but chose to stay in bed and let the ship die. This is the part that feels like a story failure.

Even though the mush are supposed to destroy the ship, it seems a better goal and a better game to me if they infiltrate the rebel Sol bases or Eden. Let's face it, the Daedalus is small fry to a solar-system spanning hive mind: it's best used as a means to an end. So in retrospect I could have strengthened my cover by trekking to the engine room and loading fuel, hoping I could eventually Anonymush if/when Terrence was killed and hopefully ride back to Sol with the crew for a surprise victory. It would have been a better story, but the ship was probably going to die from hull damage and oxygen loss so perhaps not a very likely one.

Thanks to Chun, Eleesha and the other active & communicative players on the ship - you know who you were. It was a snafu but an interesting paranoid one, which seems the point of the game after all.

On december 7, 2014

Janice or Raluca, for instance. Never pick the comms manager or captain, the next-in-lines are questionable as well. On december 8, 2014
Pave

In more simple English generally speaking to every-player reading this:
Resist the urge to play this game if you're 100%-certain you're not able to play consistently during the ship. Or at least inform when you're not able to login and such.

To be frank, unlike Die2Nite where the "live-event" coordination is much more forgiving considering the fixed amount of actions you can carry per day, Mush is surprisingly forgiving (and could be even more if it was using something similar to "Time-Units" instead of fixed / static point system, even if TU might bring some micro-management-issues).

Maybe the biggest reason for the inactivity lays (gosh, why this word has to be one of the most difficult ones to handle in English...) within the fact that people are playing Mush like they would be playing Die2Nite, in which you can pretty much do everything else except scavenging "just a moment before the day change".
Then again, many of the inactives don't play any other Twinnoid-games than Mush...


Regardless: Point still being that if you know well before hand being too busy or even able to check in twice a day or something similar (heavily depending to which character you pick), then wait until you have to the time to play; it's pretty much the same thing with more or less regular table-top-sessions where you're always missing "that guy" after much organizing and such...

Emergencies and such are fully acceptable though...
